Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E/Collaborative Research: Genetic Algorithm Driven Hybrid Computational/Experimental Engineering of Defects in Designer Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative research is to build a computational framework with experimental validation to systematically engineer designer materials that provide targeted properties. Defects in materials significantly influence their properties, for instance in energy transfer. The current state-of-the-art techniques allow one to induce defects in materials controllably and subsequently predict and correlate relevant properties to the defect concentration. In this research, computational and experimental approaches will be integrated to construct designer defect-engineered materials that will provide desired properties. In this approach, first a targeted property will be ascertained, and then the defect concentration and distribution will be predicted to synthesize novel material structures that provide the predetermined property. The hybrid computational framework will motivate the general scientific community to leverage advanced computing infrastructures. The efforts will establish new research and learning communities for computational-experimental data-enabled science and engineering through promotion of diversity and undergraduate research experience, outreach to community college students and work-force development, outreach to the general public (through education about the power of simulation-based engineering with an online gaming tool and hands-on activities at science centers) and integration of research with education.

This project is a comprehensive effort to rigorously integrate developments in high throughput synthesis and characterization with improving access and availability to high performance computing resources towards solving an inverse design of materials problem. A computational framework that sweeps through millions of possible structural permutations and combinations for property prediction will be developed and validated against experiments. The framework will (1) employ massively parallel molecular dynamics simulations to predict transport properties of nanomaterials, (2) synthesize defect engineered nanostructures and measure the corresponding transport properties, (3) integrate the above nanoscale computations and experiments through a genetic algorithm based hybrid optimization scheme to predict the optimal material structure for specified transport properties and formulate a hierarchy of increasingly complex duals of cost-functionals and design parameters, and finally (4) close the loop by validating the inverse design results experimentally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goals of the project were to implement a simulations-driven design paradigm for the discovery of novel materials with targeted material properties. Defect engineered nanomaterials were used as a testbed, specifically thermal properties of two-dimensional and heterostructures of graphene containing vacancy and isotope defects. The integrated computational framework consisted of atomistic simulations (molecular dynamics, density functional theory calculations) and nature-inspired metaheuristic optimization (genetic algorithm, cuckoo-search) using a fault-tolerant computing platform. The results were validated against collaborative experiments at the University of California, Riverside, and the simulation-based design tool was further applied to a variety of problems ranging from metalorganic perovskites used in photovoltaics, compositions of metallic alloys, geometric features of a wind turbine blade, and identification of optimal crop characteristics via plant physiology modeling. 

 

Some of the key Intellectual Merit related outcomes of the project were:

 

1. In the presence of defects that induce a mass disorder in a material, thermal conductivity reductions occur due to the perturbed motion of the atomic lattice modes. 

 

2. Thermal conductivity of soft materials is affected by the addition of nanoparticle fillers due to increase in the solid contact area relative to the effect of porous features within the material. 

 

3. Computational modifications of an optimization framework through use of encoded chromosomal approach and GPU architecture via NVIDIA’s CUDA for function evaluations accelerated the convergence of the algorithms. 

 

4. Both defect concentration and distribution influence the transport properties of materials, and hence its design. 

 

5. Establishing computational methods for property prediction and description of transport phenomena, directly complementing experimental observations of the same processes and properties was realized. Simulating large systems that reflect the experimentally observed behavior and properties, and explain the underlying phenomenon for reduced and saturated thermal conductivities was achieved.

 

Some of the key Broader Impact related outcomes of the project were:

 

1. The project has contributed towards the development and implementation of novel nanotechnology curriculum on heat transfer at the atomic scale. The course materials are available from the PI and the outcomes of the curriculum development have been documented in the archival literature for use by interested readers. 

 

2. An iPhone App NanoSim was developed and distributed, that has gained wide appreciation for its effort in bringing research advances related to the project right into the hand of any person accessing the software. 

 

3. The project provided computational and experimental training to undergraduate and graduate students, especially in the context of materials design. The workforce training aspects of the project contributed to enabling the next generation of engineers and scientists to incorporate computational (and computer/data enabled) thinking and analysis, in conjunction with experimental observations, when solving other societal problems.

 

4. The project extended research opportunities to multiple graduate and undergraduate students, and the project efforts were leveraged to mentor students from community colleges and underrepresented minority groups in STEM fields.

 

5. The project has resulted in over sixteen (16) journal publications, in addition to conference presentations, book chapters and an edited book. All these efforts contributed to the research dissemination.
